utterances: The book is Ray Bradbury's ""A Sound Of Thunder And Other Stories."" It was recommended by Jason Sheehan.
His latest novel is ""Tales From The Radiation Age.
In Libya, the tide has certainly turned against Moammar Gadhafi, and that has left an uncomfortable question for the new rebel authority - how to treat Gadhafi's loyalists?
NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro has been spending time with some nervous Gadhafi's supporters and she sent this report from Tripoli.
After the rebel takeover of Tripoli a week ago, Ahmed Tarhouni was certain he was going to be killed.
He moved from house to house, never sleeping in the same place twice.
He rarely ventured out and lied about his name.
Then about mid week, his worst fears were realized.
At a rebel checkpoint here fighters happened to hand one of his relatives a list of wanted men and Ahmed Tarhouni's name was at the top of it.
Unidentified Man #1: (Foreign language spoken)
That relative, who was shown the list, spoke to NPR and asked not to have his name used.
He says Tarhouni, once he knew about the list, became terrified and desperately tried to scramble fuel and money to flee the capital.
Unidentified Man #1: (Foreign language spoken)
But the legacy of this war goes deeper than just divisions between rival factions.
It's fractured families as well.
That's NPR's Nell Greenfieldboyce.
Mr.
H.
DULLY: Today Rebecca brings along her husband David.
They've been married 19 years, but he's never been here before, never laid eyes on his mother-in-law.
Basically, it's been so painful, I've tried to stay very far away from it for a long time.
Kind of like if you leave it alone, it'll go away.
But it never goes away.
Mr. H.
DULLY: What has changed your mind about hiding from it now?
You.
Do you know how many people you're championing?
Do you know how many people that can't do what you're doing and you're doing it for them?
Mr. H.
DULLY: It does wonders to know that other people have the same pain.
The loss.
Mr. H.
DULLY: It's a loss that you can't ever get made up.
After two years of searching, my journey is finally over.
I'll never know what I lost in those 10 minutes with Dr. Freeman and his ice pick.
By some miracle, it didn't turn me into a zombie, crush my spirit or kill me, but it did affect me deeply.
Walter Freeman's operation was supposed to relieve suffering; in my case, it did just the opposite.
Ever since my lobotomy, I've felt like a freak, ashamed.
But sitting in this room with Rebecca Welch and her mom, I know that my suffering is over.
I know my lobotomy didn't touch my soul.
For the first time, I feel no shame.
I am, at last, at peace.
Ms. McGEE & Ms. WELCH: (Singing) ...please don't take my sunshine away.
Mr. H.
DULLY: This is Howard Dully.
That's it.
(Soundbite of McGee laughing; music)
My Lobotomy was produced by Piya Kochhar and Dave Isay at Sound Portraits Productions, with help from Larry Blood and Jack El-Hai.
The editor was Gary Covino.
Pictures of Howard Dully, a history of lobotomy and other stories of people who underwent Walter Freeman's procedure can be found at our Web site, npr.org.
This is NPR, National Public Radio.
Since the creation of a national intelligence czar, there have been questions about where this new role would leave the head of the CIA.
How would the two intelligence chiefs divide power?
What's their relationship with each other and the president?
Now the disclosure of a White House memo is shedding light on the growing power of the national director of intelligence, John Negroponte, at the expense of the CIA.
Timothy Burger reports on the memo in the latest issue of Time magazine.
Mr.
Burger, welcome.
Thank you.
Your article is called: Sidelining the CIA.
What does this memo say?

The memo says that the new director of national intelligence, John Negroponte, will take over the reins of advising the National Security Council and the regular seat that the CIA director, Porter Goss, used to hold.
And so what does that mean for Mr. Goss?
Well, it means Mr. Goss will go basically back to running the CIA full time.
That's been sort of a part-time job for the CIA director because he used to have the role of director of Central Intelligence also.
That vanished when Mr. Negroponte took office, and now the CIA director can full-time go run the nation's human intelligence collection and intelligence analysis machine.
I mean, the title of your article suggests this is basically diminishing the powers of Mr. Goss.
Do you get any sense that CIA Chief Porter Goss is upset by this latest memo that says he's not necessarily at these meetings?

I don't know a hundred percent of his personal attitude toward it, but we have a window on that with a speech that he made in March, where he said that he was spending six hours a day preparing just to brief President Bush every morning.

So if you add to that the National Security Council meetings, many of which are not directly related to the CIA's core mission, I wouldn't be surprised if Porter Goss doesn't mind not having a bunch of meetings to go to, where he can focus inward on fixing problems at the agency.
This isn't to say that the CIA director is banished from the White House, by any means.
I'm sure if Porter Goss found that there was some problem that, in his judgment, needed the president's immediate attention, he could pick up the phone, and the message would get through.
The point is that the CIA director will be invited to NSC meetings where it's relevant to his mission or the human intelligence or analysis mission of the CIA.
He won't have to go if it's sort of meetings, say--I don't know--on the European economy or, you know, `Will the euro hold up?
or, you know, `How is the Chinese currency faring against the dollar?
He would be less likely to go to meetings like that.
But if you're saying, `How do we penetrate the Iranian mullah regime?
that would be more the kind of thing that he would attend.
So how do you see the changing role of the CIA?

I think that if everyone is acting like adults, which doesn't happen all the time in Washington--but one hopes they will in this case--then Porter Goss can spend basically all his time trying to fix the CIA, which has come under a lot of criticism after 9/11 and the Iraq problem.
We have to have better human intelligence; no one disputes that.
We need to know what North Korea's up to--and Iran.
And at the same time, the analysis needs to be repaired so we don't have prewar intelligence about a regime that ends up being so far off, as it was with Iraq.
Timothy Burger is an intelligence correspondent for Time magazine.
Thank you.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Hello.
So RunKeeper started as a way for runners to keep track of their runs.
And now it's for other kinds of exercise, too - for walking, for biking, for swimming.
Rather than having that mileage clicker on my hip, I'd be carrying this phone, and it's going to keep track of where I go?
Right.
Exactly.
So you carry the phone and you start the app.
And it uses the, you know, the GPS chip in the phone to figure out where you were, where you started from.
It also can tell how fast you're going.
And the great thing is that it does this automatically, so each time you run, it just keeps this data.
And then you can go back and look at RunKeeper.com, and it keeps a very detailed list of all your stats.
And it also says here - there's a function inside this program, post to Twitter, posts to Facebook.
So I could announce to the world that I ran 13 miles, or that I actually got rather tired of the whole exercise after about four blocks and walked home.
Either way, it'll be on...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Yeah.

I mean, I think the theory is that if people are looking at your runs and if you're kind of sharing them with other people, you might be motivated to actually keep up with the running because you might want to impress other people.
But once we finish our rigorous exercise, we can go try this other app on the smartphone, which is called Chefs Feed.
And there's a subtitle on here, now that I've loaded it.
And the subtitle is: I'll have what their having.
Is that the whole deal?
This is an app, it's kind of designed exclusively for foodies.
And so Chefs Feed works - it's a review app like Yelp, for example where, you know, it tells you various restaurants to go to.
But the only reviewers here are famous chefs.
So it tells you the places that, you know, chefs you might admire go to themselves - and not their own restaurants, other restaurants.
Oh, okay.
Looks I can do New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, some other places, San Francisco.
Yeah.
And they - on the website, they say they're going to be adding more cities soon.
But right now, it's just the big cities.
